column16: I appreciate the alignment of this work to the CCDS. It would be great to see how this work will incorporate disparate datasets available through various PRO related surveys. It is unclean how this aligns with the PROMIS item set.
column17: It is unclean how this aligns with the PROMIS item set.

column16: Expand the exampes to include more that are relevant to the use cases of PRO/PROM.  The examples are more relevant to questionnaires than PRO/PROM.  I saw only 1 example that was representative of a PRO/PROM – assessing functional status by selecting option 2.  All the others are examples of questionnaires such as for a patient completing a previsit questionnaire for current medication and past medical and family history.  There should be more examples where there is a “controlled/predefined” list of response options for each question so that responses can be quantified.
column17: Expand the exampes to include more that are relevant to the use cases of PRO/PROM

The following are excluded from the scope of this submission:
● Intelligent devices (such as infusion pumps, cardiac pacemaker and implantable cardioversion defibrillator) that generates actionable data and perform AI algorithmic actions

1.	Validating patient reported outcomes is important. Consider the extent to which free text is used as well as the best practices for the Questionnaire FHIR Resource.
column17: Consider the extent to which free text is used as well as the best practices for the Questionnaire FHIR Resource.

column16: 2.2.	Sharing PROs to parties beyond providers and authorized researchers is needed and beneficial in some cases. Expanding who the data is made available to once captured is important. Revisiting the bolded statement is requested: “The Patient Reported Outcomes (PRO) FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) will focus on capturing and exchanging patient reported outcome data electronically using the FHIR standard. The data that is captured will be made available to both providers and authorized researchers.” Would “and authorized parties” be more acceptable?
column17: Sharing PROs to parties beyond providers and authorized researchers is needed and beneficial in some cases.
